coredata.dc:title: Structural insights into solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) on lithium metal anode: From design strategies to the stability evaluation
coredata.dc:creator: Tan, Jian
Ma, Longli
Li, Zhiheng
Wang, Yuan
Ye, Mingxin
Shen, Jianfeng
coredata.dc:description: Solid electrolyte interphase (SEI), known as an ionic conductor but electronic insulator, plays a dominant role in cycling stability and safety of rechargeable lithium metal batteries (RLMBs). Although tremendous endeavors have been devoted to identifying the chemical component and spatial distribution of SEI, the linkage between exact nanostructure and its stability still remains to be clarified. In this highly focused research area, plenty of profound papers have been published. However, structural insights, designing guidelines and corresponding stability evaluation approaches of SEI film are still not comprehensively summarized. In this review, we extract major breakthroughs of SEI structure, and then elucidate the mechanism insights of SEI film, including formation mechanism and transportation mechanism of Li+ in the SEI film. Subsequently, we systematically summarize the design principles and strategies for a stable SEI film. Afterwards, we propose general evaluation standards for the stability of SEI film, including chemical/electrochemical methods, atomic-level characterization techniques, and theoretical calculations. Finally, personal perspectives on the construction of stable SEI film are provided at the end of the manuscript. We envision that this timely review can be used as a handy reference for designing stable SEI films with a unique nanostructure and motivate researchers to build better RLMBs.

head.ce:title: Structural insights into solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) on lithium metal anode: From design strategies to the stability evaluation

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: By revisiting the physicochemical property of lithium (Li) metal and its microscopic structure, summarizing the fundamental understanding of SEI film, including its formation mechanism, transportation mechanism of Li+ in it, design principles and strategies for a stable SEI film, and atomic-level characterization techniques, as well as theoretical calculations, proposing general evaluation standards for the stability of SEI film. Finally, we propose insightful perspectives on the future of this critical topic. This perspective aims to provide structural insights into SEI for developing practical rechargeable Li metal batteries.

Solid electrolyte interphase (SEI), known as an ionic conductor but electronic insulator, plays a dominant role in cycling stability and safety of rechargeable lithium metal batteries (RLMBs). Although tremendous endeavors have been devoted to identifying the chemical component and spatial distribution of SEI, the linkage between exact nanostructure and its stability still remains to be clarified. In this highly focused research area, plenty of profound papers have been published. However, structural insights, designing guidelines and corresponding stability evaluation approaches of SEI film are still not comprehensively summarized. In this review, we extract major breakthroughs of SEI structure, and then elucidate the mechanism insights of SEI film, including formation mechanism and transportation mechanism of Li+ in the SEI film. Subsequently, we systematically summarize the design principles and strategies for a stable SEI film. Afterwards, we propose general evaluation standards for the stability of SEI film, including chemical/electrochemical methods, atomic-level characterization techniques, and theoretical calculations. Finally, personal perspectives on the construction of stable SEI film are provided at the end of the manuscript. We envision that this timely review can be used as a handy reference for designing stable SEI films with a unique nanostructure and motivate researchers to build better RLMBs.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: Data will be made available on request.

ce:section.ce:para: The past few decades have witnessed an extensive investigation on electrolyte/anode interface in lithium (Li)-based rechargeable batteries. It was in 1990 that a key breakthrough was made by Dahn and colleagues who used ethylene carbonate (EC) instead of propylene carbonate (PC) as the primary solvent of electrolyte for Li-ion batteries (LIBs) [1]. Surprisingly, the researchers had discovered that LIBs with graphite as the anode achieved an ultralong cycling lifetime, which is attributed to the surface protective film, so-called “solid electrolyte interphase (SEI)” formed on the side of graphite anode [2]. After this major breakthrough, rechargeable Li-ion batteries (RLIBs) were successfully commercialized in 1991 by Sony Corporation. Logically, the finding of SEI film is considered as the final piece of the jigsaw for the commercial applications of RLIBs. Indubitably, RLIBs have been reckoned as one of the landmark inventions in contemporary society and have an unprecedented impact on our world, permeating every aspect of our lives, including various consumer portable electronic products, electric vehicles (EVs), optoelectronic devices, and so on. To reward those scientists who made outstanding contributions to the commercialization of LIBs, the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences in Stockholm has awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry 2019 to John B. Goodenough and M. Stanley Whittingham from the United States, and Akira Yoshino from Japan. Although those pioneers who discovered SEI film were not rewarded, this does not mean that SEI film is not significant, which has instead been gained increasing attention and investment in the follow-up research.

Currently, a situation must be accepted that the energy density of current state-of-the-art RLIBs using graphite as the anode has approached its theoretical value (300 Wh kg−1) [3–6], which falls short of meeting the further requirements for the aforementioned devices. To circumvent this intrinsic limitations, scientific researchers must keep close eyes on the other secondary batteries with higher energy densities. Among these existing front-runners, rechargeable Li metal batteries (RLMBs) have returned in vogue and ushered in the emerging opportunities in the past several decades. This is mainly because Li metal as the anode owns an ultrahigh theoretical specific capacity of 3860 mAh g−1 and the lowest electrode potential of −3.04 V (vs. the standard hydrogen electrode (SHE)) amongst all available anode materials [3,5,7–9]. More significantly, when Li metal as the anode is paired with a high-voltage and high-capacity cathode, RLMBs can deliver a higher energy density than that of current state-of-the-art RLIBs. Unfortunately, the fatal growth of Li dendrites mainly caused by unstable SEI film affects RLMBs’ safety, which has been considered as a stumbling block for RLMBs towards the practical applications.

In this regard, a myriad of efforts have been devoted to overcoming the above-mentioned challenge, including designing artificial SEI film on the surface of Li metal anodes [10–25], exploring new types of electrolytes [26–44], developing advanced separators [45–51], designing three dimensional (3D)-structured electrodes [52,53], and so on. All of these strategies share a common core, that is, creating a robust SEI film on the surface of Li metal anode, and claimed that they can effectively suppress the growth of Li dendrites and prolong the cycle stability of RLMBs. Although these strategies are scientifically exciting and effectively improve the electrochemical performance of batteries, most of data obtained based on coin cells or single sided coating are still far from the energy density that are practically demanded to reach and need to be further optimized in pouch cells. More importantly, these strategies cannot completely tame the formation of Li dendrites, so that the quest for more reliable and practical methods has been continuing. It can be noticed that the “stable” SEI film is frequently used to elucidate the enhanced electrochemical performance of RLMBs. Fig. 1 provides a brief timeline of so called stable SEI films from 2017 to 2023. As a matter of fact, these so called stable SEI films can be mainly divided into three categories based on their main constituents, including inorganic-rich SEI film, organic-rich SEI film, and inorganic–organic hybrid SEI film. However, owing to the lack of available characterization techniques, it is hard to establish the relationship between the exact nanostructure and stability of SEI film and the improved electrochemical performance of batteries. According to the conventional recognition, a stable SEI film must be featured by a high ionic conductor but excellent electronic insulator [54–57]. More precisely, it should be responsible for maintaining conductive to Li ion (Li+) while blocking electron (e-) tunneling to prevent the electrolyte from being further reductively decomposed on the surface of Li metal anode. It seems that the conventional understanding about the ionic conductive but electron insulating properties is reasonable in theory but limited in practice.

Although SEI film has been extensively studied in chemical constituent, spatial structure, and microscopic morphology, it is still treated as the most complex but the least understood component so far. Currently, most researchers treat stable SEI film as a continuous and dense structure under macroscopic level and present it in form of schematic drawing, which can indeed help readers to understand the superiority of stable SEI film. Nonetheless, to a certain extent, it is a misleading way since “stable” is a broad term, as we do not know whether stable SEI film is a continual and dense structure from the microscopic perspective, especially at the atomistic level. As we all know, LMB is a macroscopic device. Its operation highly depends on electrons and Li+ ions travelling back and forth between the cathode and the anode [58–60], whereas electrons and ions are both extremely tiny. When zooming into the microscale, it is very likely that the stability of SEI film in most of the reported strategies should be re-examined. Although there are considerable excellent reviews or perspectives summarizing the research progress on SEI film and concerning design strategies of stable Li metal anodes [61–74], only sporadic publications have mentioned that finding a balance between inorganic species and organic components in the SEI film is of great importance to improve their electrochemical performance [75–77]. Moreover, to the best of our knowledge, the stability indexes and designing guidelines for a stable SEI film are still lacking so far. This review attempts to fill this gap.

In this review, we firstly revisit the physicochemical property and microscopic structure of Li metal. Then, we extract the major breakthroughs on understanding the SEI film, which can provide a contextualization for critically examining new progresses in this area. Next, we provide a comprehensive discussion of the fundamental understanding of SEI film, including its formation mechanism and the transportation mechanism of Li+ in it. Subsequently, we systematically summarized the design strategies of a stable SEI film. Afterwards, we propose general evaluation standards for the stability of SEI film, including chemical/electrochemical methods, the characterization techniques, and theoretical calculations. Finally, we present conclusions and personal perspectives on where the RLMBs technology should go next. The overall structure of this review is presented in Fig. 2 . We envision that this timely review will deepen the understanding on SEI structure and navigate the design of a stable SEI film on the surface of Li metal in future research.

ce:section.ce:section-title: A brief overview of Li metal
ce:section.ce:para: Before discussing the formation of SEI film, we need to understand the high reactivity of Li metal deeply. As was mentioned previously, owing to the lowest electrode potential (-3.04 V vs. SHE), Li metal can react with almost all electrolytes to form a layer of passivation film. Noticeably, this layer of passivating film is typically heterogeneous and brittle, which can trigger a series of problems, including SEI film crack, the formation of Li dendrites, and fresh Li exposure. Once fresh Li metal is exposed to the electrolyte, a new SEI film will be inevitably formed. Therefore, the repeated destruction and remodeling of the SEI film form a terrible closed loop (Fig. 3b). Understandably, this is the reason why various efforts have been devoted to designing high-quality SEI film on the surface of Li metal anode, which has been treated as a prerequisite for expending the cycle lifetime of practical RLMBs.

Zooming into the microscale, a Li metal foil generally consists of a large number of crystal grains, which can form different types of grains boundaries (GBs) and crystal facets on the surface of Li metal foil (Fig. 3c). It is worth noting that crystal facets or GBs can both react with electrolytes [81]. As a body-center cubic (BCC) structure, (110), (200), and (211) crystal facets of Li metal are the main crystallographic features (Fig. 3d) [82]. Among them, the (110) crystal facet has been considered as the most stable crystal plane owing to its lowest surface energy (Fig. 3e) [75,83], which has been widely accepted as the preferential crystallographic facet of Li metal during electrodeposition process [75,82,84–86]. If the Li metal anode keeps growing along the (110) crystal facet, Li dendrites will be formed eventually. Therefore, in order to fundamentally alleviate the uncontrollable growth of Li dendrites and unfriendly parasitic reactions, researchers have to fabricate stable Li metal anodes from the crystallographic perspective.

Nowadays, regulating crystallography of Li deposits is a highly focused topic, which is beyond the scope of this review, and we encourage the readers to consult the recent excellent reviews [87–89]. It is worth noting that the effect of surface texturing of commercial Li metal on Li plating/stripping behavior and the electrochemical performance of batteries is still an uncultivated land, which deserves to be deeply explored in future research.

As we mentioned in the previous paragraph, it was in 1991 when RLIBs were successfully commercialized. As a matter of fact, the research on RLMBs predates research that of RLIBs. However, RLMBs research has been put on hold for a long time owing to safety accidents. Since 2010, the philosophy of building higher energy density batteries pushes the rapid development of RLMBs, and the number of publications on RLMBs presenting an exponential increase tendency is the best embodiment (Fig. 4 a). In recent years, a considerable amount of research on RLMBs focuses on SEI film, whose publications also present an exponential growth, from a trickle in the early days evolving into a current wave (Fig. 4b). It is unrealistic to provide a complete retrospect on this huge body of group. As a contextualization, we extract some major breakthroughs related to SEI film to revisit its structure for enlightening the future research.

The first significant milestone occurred in 1979 when Peled pioneeringly realized that the interface between Li metal and electrolyte is an ionic conductor yet electron insulator, formally defined it as SEI film, and proposed the first model [2]. After 18 years (in 1997), Peled and co-authors further enriched the model as multi-components, multi-layer model [56]. From the schematic diagram, it is found that in the side of Li or carbon electrode, there are some inorganic compounds, like LiF, Li2O, Li2CO3, which are thermodynamically stable against Li metal anode. In the side of electrolyte, some inorganic components are displayed (Fig. 5 a). Since then, various models of SEI film have been speculated and schematically illustrated [75,90,91]. but without any significant difference in the key mechanism that explain the improvement of electrochemical performance of batteries, and almost all researches attribute the improved electrochemical performances to robust SEI film formed on the surface of Li metal anodes. In fact, this is a kind of vague explanation. Until 2017, Li et al. [75] observed the atomic resolution image using cryo-EM. From the atomic resolution point of view, it is found that SEI film presents amorphous matrix instead of continuous and dense structure on the side of Li metal under both two different electrolytes. Noticeably, even in fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) electrolyte environment, Li2O dominates in the side of electrolyte rather than LiF. Based on the cryo-EM results, the authors proposed two different models of SEI film: mosaic model and multilayer model (Fig. 5b). Since then, researchers have an in-depth understanding on the structure of SEI film. A year after, Li et al. [77] continued to recruit cryo-EM to investigate the correlating structure and function of the battery interface from the atomic scale. The researchers detailly elucidated the function of mosaic film and multilayer SEI film, and contented that crystalline grain distribution within the SEI film could be treated as the key feature leading to the differential electrochemical performance of RLMBs (Fig. 5c). Impressively, the authors pointed out that crystalline grains formed by inorganic species must be uniformly distributed within an amorphous organic polymer matrix, which can result in the uniform ionic conductivity.

In 2019, Cao et al. [90] proposed a monolayer structure, which is significantly different from the mosaic- or multilayer-type SEI films reported by Li and co-authors [75]. Although energy dispersive spectroscopy revealed that the SEI film derived from Li bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide (LiFSI) contains inorganic-rich species, they were not crystallized but exist in the form of amorphous matrix on the surface of Li metal (Fig. 5d). In the same year, Wang et al. [9] observed a new nanostructure SEI film formed at different temperatures using cryo-EM. When the temperature was increased to 60 °C, the structure of SEI film is composed of a multilayer and continuous Li2O layer, which formed on the top of the inner amorphous layer (Fig. 5e). Moreover, SEI films exhibit different structures even in the same electrolyte at different temperatures. Differently, in 2020, Yu et al. [29] designed different electrolyte solvents from the molecular level, enabling energy-dense and long-cycling LMBs. From the above mentioned cryo-EM images, it is found that the SEI film presents a non-uniform and non-compact structure in specific electrolyte (1 M LiFSI/DME), while it is amorphous and homogeneous in the fluorinated electrolyte (Fig. 5f), despite the solvent molecule is only difference of four F functional groups. This work suggests that SEI film can present different structure within different electrolytes. From the perspective of the models aforementioned above [9,29,75,90], it is found that the SEI film is not continuous and dense at the nanoscale, and some are of even amorphous structure. In 2020, by using in-situ liquid secondary ion mass spectrometry (liquid-SIMS), Zhou et al. [91] verified that the SEI film can be divided into two layers. One layer is an inner SEI layer close to the side of anode, while the other layer is an outer SEI layer approaching to the side of electrolyte. The inner SEI layer is continuous, compact and impermeable to electrolytes, which is dominated by Li2O with a thickness of 15–20 nm rather than LiF, while the outer SEI layer is mainly composed of loose organic oligomers, which is permeable to electrolytes (Fig. 5g). Some of the above-mentioned cases strongly consider that SEI film is dense and continued [91], but they are expressed in form of schematic illustration in the macroscopic level, which is rather different from the nanoscale.

The past two years have witnessed the major breakthroughs on the understanding of SEI film [92,93]. In particular, in 2021, Liu, Xiao and colleagues [92] firstly proposed the concept of dry SEI film, where the researchers were trying to elucidate the underlying degradation mechanisms and capacity fading models between thin Li metal and thick Li metal pouch cells. They advocated that dry SEI film is not involved in subsequent electrochemical reactions owing to the lack of ion conduction pathways and the thinner the Li metal foil, the less Li is available for the parasitic reactions, and thus the thinner the SEI film is (Fig. 5h). The previous experimental data based on X-ray photoelectronic spectroscope (XPS) [94], and Cryo-EM [9,29,75,76,90,94–96] were obtained under high vacuum environment, without the presence of electrolyte solution. Recently, a research group led by Cui has originally developed a thin film vitrification method for characterizing SEI film under high vacuum condition [93]. Interestingly, they found a swelling phenomenon of SEI film in electrolyte environment. More precisely, the thickness of SEI film is just ∼10 nm under ‘‘dry” state (without electrolyte solution). As a significant comparison, the thickness of SEI film is ∼20 nm under vitrified electrolyte environment (this condition can be treated as ‘‘wet” state) (Fig. 5i), which means that SEI film might not be a compact layer and exist an amount of electrolyte solution. The researchers concluded that SEI film is not a dense interface and allows electrolyte penetration [93], which poses a challenge on the conventional understanding on SEI film that can prevent liquid electrolyte from directly contacting electrode. Interestingly, the authors found that the lower swelling ratio of SEI film with inorganic-rich species is, the higher Coulombic efficiency (CE) is. This work challenges the previous understanding and has roused great controversy in academic community.

In summary, looking back to the major breakthroughs on the SEI film, its understanding undergoes a transition from ignorance to consensus, and from conceptual presentation to direct visualization. Moreover, understanding on SEI film has recently emerged controversy. According to these previous reports, we summarize the in-situ SEI film observed by cryo-EM. It can be seen that the thickness of SEI film in-situ formed is rather thin, from 6 to 35 nm, as shown in Table 2 . Although different structure of SEI film have been observed, it still remains unclear about the relationship between SEI model and electrochemical performance, which is worth allotting more funds and devoting more efforts.

Although the research on SEI film has made some impressive progress and breakthroughs, until now, we still do not know the relationship between the structure of SEI film and electrochemical performance, while the improved electrochemical performances of most studies are vaguely attributed to the stable SEI film. To better delve into this issue, we need to deeply understand the formation mechanism of SEI film, transportation mechanism of Li+ in the SEI film, and solvation electrolyte in nanoconfined environment in the following part.

Before the discussion of the formation mechanism of SEI film, it is necessary to present a brief introduction on the electric double layer (EDL). The concept of the EDL was firstly proposed by Helmholtz who contended that a charged surface immersed in an electrolyte solution can attract their counterions, which is called as the Helmholtz model. Later, the Helmholtz model was improved and enriched by Gouy and Chapman, which is named as Gouy–Chapman model. In 1924, Stern combined the Helmholtz model and Gouy–Chapman model to elucidate the detailed structure of EDL, which is known as Stern model, where exists ion arrangements (Fig. 6 a) [97]. Up to now, Stern model is still the foundation of the theoretical description of interfaces [62,98–100]. In a word, the EDL is composed of a layer of charges at the surface of electrode and a layer of counterions in the electrolyte. Based on this theory, in the LMB system, when Li metal contacts electrolyte, solvated Li+ originating from the bulk electrolyte can be immediately adsorbed on the surface of Li metal, which means that solvent molecules can be preferentially reduced. In addition to the spontaneous chemical reaction, when Li metal is placed in organic electrolyte, electrochemical reduction reaction can also occur due to the relatively low redox potential of most of common organic solvents (1.0 V vs. Li/Li+). Those formed insoluble products covering on the surface of Li metal are named as so-called SEI film.

Over the past few decades, considerable efforts have been devoted to investigating the formation mechanism of SEI film on the surface of Li metal anode, whose formation process generally contains reduction and decomposition of electrolyte solution (solute and solvent). The formation mechanism of SEI film will not be covered here, as it has been recently discussed by Chen and colleagues [101]. However, two formation mechanisms have been put forward in battery science, despite some controversies. The first one is coined by Peled who advocated that the surface chemical reaction of Li metal is gradual and preferential reduction of specific components in electrolyte solution [2]. The second one is the mosaic model proposed by Kanamura and co-authors who contended that several insoluble reduced products be deposited simultaneously on Li metal anode to form a mosaic structure [102]. The aforementioned explanation on the SEI film formation is general consensus. How the SEI film is formed on the surface of Li metal at the atomic level? In order to response this question, Yu et al. [103] presented a schematic diagram of SEI film formation, as shown in Fig. 6b. It can be seen that LiF formed by spontaneous reaction is firmly anchored on the surface of Li metal with the form of chemical bonds. Based on this diagram, we are curious how subsequent Li+ ions deposit at this interface, where there is not enough room to accommodate so many Li atoms. Perhaps, this is the mystery of SEI film, which deserves to be explored in-depth in future research.

It is well known that organic electrolyte is made up of Li salts and organic solvents, both of which can be reduced when electrolyte contacts Li metal, meaning that they participate in the formation of SEI film. To explore the reaction mechanism between two anions and Li metal, Miao et al. [104] designed a novel electrolyte solution containing organic Li salt (LiTFSI), inorganic Li salt (LiFSI), and DOL/DME mixed solvents. The researchers discovered that FSI- and TFSI-anions competitively react with Li metal owing to different bonding energy of S-F and S-CF3, while -SO2F group from FSI- anion is more aggressively reactive than -SO2CF3 group from TFSI- anion with Li metal. It is worth noting that the reaction selection largely limits to fluorinated anions. The splitting F ion in the cleavage of S-F bond can form LiF, leading to the formation of an inorganic-rich SEI film on the surface of Li metal (Fig. 6c). Theoretically, the carbon-containing segment is reduced to the organic components, which is covalently bonded to Li atoms, while the inorganic components derived from carbon-free inorganic segment binds with Li atoms in the form of ionic bonds. Conventionally, SEI film is regarded to be formed by the chemical and electrochemical reactions between Li metal and electrolyte. However, a recent study reported by Hu and colleagues [105] challenges this conventional viewpoint. The researchers contended that considerable contributions of SEI film are from electrolyte, cathode, moisture and native species on the surface of Li metal surface. Moreover, it is highly dynamic during charging-discharging cycling.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Transportation mechanism of Li+ in the SEI film
ce:section.ce:para: After a certain understanding of the chemical composition existing in the SEI film, it is urgent to deeply elucidate its microscopic structure. The past 40 years have witnessed substantial explorations on the SEI film. However, it is utmost challenging to experimentally identify the diffusion pathway of Li+ ions inside the SEI film under working condition. Fortunately, theoretical calculation, as a powerful tool, has developed into a branch of scientific research and been widely used in the field of electrochemical energy storage, especially in understanding of SEI film.

In order to understand which components in an electrolyte dominate the SEI film, theoretical calculations based on density functional theory (DFT) have been recruited to predict the order of decomposition. As was mentioned previously, first-principle calculations have shown that the Li+ diffuses faster along the heterogeneous GBs than individual domains [81,106,107]. Representatively, Ramasubramanian et al. [106,107] have recently confirmed that Li+ ions diffusion occurs through the open channels formed by the GBs based on the first-principles DFT calculations. Moreover, the authors also found that Li+ ions diffusion in the GB is faster than in the neighboring crystalline regions within the grain interiors (Fig. 7 a) [106]. Through transport experiments and theoretical calculations, Kranz et al. [108] stated that even a tiny amount of porosity of the SEI film can lead to Li+ transportation governed by the liquid-phase transport pathways (Fig. 7b). This result challenges the common standpoint of a solid-electrolyte-type transportation mechanism. It is worthy to be noted that recruiting theoretical simulations can provide researchers with much atomic understanding on the SEI film, but it is mostly based on the ideal condition, where exists a lot of assumptions. Therefore, there is a big gap between actual state and theoretical simulations. Several studies demonstrated an enhancement of ionic conductivity when inorganic nanoparticles are dispersed in solid polymer electrolytes [109,110], which is quite resemble with the SEI film. Representatively, Liu et al. [110] stated that the transportation of Li+ ions is non-uniform when inorganic nanocrystalline are randomly distributed in the solid electrolyte (Fig. 7c), which is exactly considered as the major reason of Li dendrites formation [77].

As early as in 2007, Xu et al. [111] systematically elucidated the migration process of a solvated Li+ from the bulk solution to SEI film to graphite anode, which includes three step: solvated Li+ diffusion in the bulk electrolyte, breakup of Li+ solvation shell, and diffusion of bare Li+ though the SEI film. It is noteworthy that desolvation has been validated as the main energy-consuming step, which is considered as the rate-limiting step in the whole charge process [112]. Empirically, the understanding of the above process is similar, except that the graphite anode is replaced by the Li metal anode. Once the solvated Li+ in bulk solution travels to the surface of SEI film under an electric field, it must de-solvate to form the “naked” Li+, and then reaches the surface of bulk Li metal electrode and is reduced as Li atom by accepting an electron from an external circuit, finally is coupled to the lattice of the original Li metal electrode [72,113]. In short, the deposition of Li atoms in the surface of Li metal anode needs to go through the processes of solvation, dissolution, nucleation and migration.

In electrolyte system, the movement of free solvent is believed to be blocked by the porosity of organic components in the SEI film. Actually, in practical conditions, the organic SEI components can be significantly swollen by solvents. The transportation of solvent molecules can only be stopped by the close packing of non-swollen inorganic components. In 2007, Xu and et al. [111] have confirmed that the Li+ desolvation process is the rate-determining step during whole electrochemical process. In order to accelerate Li+ desolvation, starting with the molecular structure of solvent, Li and colleagues [114] reduced the ion–dipole interaction between vinyl carbonate and Li+ by fluorine substitution, thereby effectively improving the interfacial reaction kinetics. The process of Li+ desolvation is vital for the dynamic performance of LMBs, especially at low temperature.

Taking the previous major breakthroughs on understanding the SEI film and theoretical calculations into account [40,110,115], we herein propose a new model and portray a well-designed schematic illustration to help readers better understand the transportation mechanism of Li+ in the SEI film (Fig. 8 ). To be specific, interfacial process contains ion desolvation at the SEI, ion transport in the SEI, and charge transfer reactions. Different from the previous publications [91], we advocate that formed organic components with a certain porosity can distribute in whole SEI film as chemical and electrochemical reaction proceed, and GBs formed by inorganic species can be covered by porous organic oligomer on the side of Li metal anode, where “naked” Li+ ions can rapidly move at the inorganic-polymer interface, while free solvent molecules cannot pass since its size is larger than the porosity of organic components. During preparing this manuscript, Meng and colleagues [116] published a review article titled “Designing better electrolytes” and specifically emphasized the importance of the solvation electrolyte in nanoconfinement environment, where an extremely fast ion transport takes place, which is confirmed by some excellent researches [117–119]. It seems that the unexpected phenomenon is unrelated in these reports, but solvated ions are indeed changing in the nanoconfinement environment, where partial or complete desolvation of the ions may occur. Obviously, considering the pore size of organic species, the size of solvation structure, bare Li+ and solvent molecules is highly necessary.

It is worth noting that Leung et al. [120] have employed the theoretical calculations based on DFT to reveal that Li2O GBs in the SEI film with large enough pores can accommodate the diffusion of “naked” Li+. Moreover, they also showed that Li-metal nanostructures as thin as 12 Å are thermodynamically stable inside Li2O cracks. After passing though SEI film, naked Li+ accepts electron from the Li surface to form Li atoms and diffuse in the deep atomic lattice [58,121]. In fact, our proposed model can exactly be used to explain why SEI film swollen under electrolyte environment. Therefore, solvation electrolyte in porous structure of organic SEI film, especially in nanoconfined environment, should be appreciated.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Microscopic structure evolution of Li metal electrodes
ce:section.ce:para: As we mentioned previously, Li metal electrodes undergo significant volume fluctuation during repetitive cycling process. In order to better understand the evolution of the Li deposition morphology, Wang et al. [122] elucidated the root cause of Li deposition coverage in enabling highly reversible and compact Li deposits by using different concentration electrolytes, depicting a comprehensive picture in the relationship between the microstructure evolution of Li metal electrodes and SEI film for LMBs by combining in situ/operando characterization techniques with ex situ experimental results. Moreover, the authors found that the higher concentrated electrolytes can trigger the formation of the inorganic-rich SEI film, which can effectively suppress the growth of Li dendrites and promote the formation of dense Li metal deposition. As a comparison, lower concentration electrolytes can induce the formation of an organic-rich instable SEI film, which can promote the formation of Li dendrites (Fig. 9 a). To in-real time monitor Li metal microstructure evolution during cycling process, very recently, Matic, Xiong and colleagues [123] developed an operando synchrotron radiation X-ray tomography (XTM) characterization technique to probe the formation, growth, and dissolution of Li metal microstructures. The authors found that the microstructures of Li deposits, like needle-like, mossy-like, and integrated structures (Fig. 9b), are both highly depends on the applied current density, and the readers can consult this excellent article for more detailed information.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Design principles for an ideal SEI film
ce:section.ce:para: Before discussing design strategies for stable SEI film, we preferentially present the design principles for an ideal SEI film. In the previous sections, we have systematically discussed pure inorganic, pure organic components, and inorganic–organic hybrid components existing in the SEI film, and highlighted their essential merits and limitations. Based on these discussions, the superiority of inorganic–organic hybrid SEI film is self-evident. Herein, it is suggested that SEI film is a compromise of opposites between inorganic nanocrystals and organic species. Pure inorganic components and pure organic species for SEI film are both unsatisfactory. Researchers need to find a balance between inorganic components and organic species existing in the SEI film. This dialectical relationship can be likened to Tai Chi in classical Chinese Philosophy [124]. In other words, there needs to be a balance between inorganic species and organic matrix since pure inorganic and all organic SEI film cannot ensure safety and durability of RLMBs. For an ideal SEI film, it must meet multiple criteria simultaneously, including high ionic conductivity and excellent electronic insulation, good adhesion, suitable thickness, excellent mechanical stability, and compactness (Fig. 10 ).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Components and composite level insights of SEI film
ce:section.ce:para: Various inorganic and organic compounds have been used as the effective components in the SEI film. Some components exhibit high band gap (electronic insulting) and high diffusion barrier (ion conductive), while others demonstrate high electronic insulting and low ion conductive (Fig. 11 a) [61]. From the property of SEI film, it seems that LiF is one of the most effective components. However, the bulk LiF is an ionic insulator (∼10-13 to 10-14 S cm−1) [13], how does the LiF function in the SEI film? Recent studies suggested that nanosized LiF has a high ionic conductivity [106,107]. Moreover, GBs formed by nanosized LiF and Li2O shows the highest ionic conductivity among three different combinations (Fig. 11b). Logically, if nanosized LiF and Li2O can be dispersed in a flexible organic/polymer matrix for SEI film, the volume expansion during charge process can be effectively regulated. However, it is highly challenging to tailor uniform heterogeneous SEI film on the surface of Li metal. In addition to nanosized LiF and Li2O, a recent work reported that nanocrystalline film consisting of Li2O and Li2S by sputter deposition can also improve Li+ transportation compared with the bulk materials (Fig. 11c) [125]. Based on the first-principles calculations, Tao and colleagues [126] simulated the Li+ possible diffusion pathway in four bulk inorganic component: LiOH, Li2O, Li2CO3, and LiF, whose crystal structures are presented in Fig. 11d. Of particular note, four inorganic crystal phases are both strong electronic insulating, so that they were frequently used as the component of SEI film. In 2005, Monroe and coauthor [245] stated that the growth of Li dendrites can be effectively prevented when the shear modulus of a separator is about twice that of Li metal by s series of theoretical derivations. Logically, engineering inorganic-rich SEI film on the surface of Li metal is a promising solution since the shear modulus of most inorganic crystals is more than twice that of Li metal (4.2 GPa) [61], including LiF, LiCl, LiBr, LiI, Al2O3, and ZnO (see Fig. 11e). In addition to shear modulus, surface energy is another key parameter to evaluate the mechanical stability of SEI film. It has been reported that the components in the SEI film with both high shear modulus and surface tension are considered to be suitable for stable electrodeposition of Li metal [61]. Among these crystals mentioned previously, it seems that LiF is the best alternative since it also shows a relatively high surface energy. It is frequently mentioned in the SEI film and used to explain the reason of enhanced electrochemical performance of batteries [62,127], and the number of publications related to LiF in the last three years present an increasing trend (Fig. 11f).

From the properties of these inorganic materials aforementioned, it is impossible to use a single component for constructing the SEI film to meet all requirements of an ideal SEI film mentioned in the last section. Atomically smooth surface, as a near-ideal SEI film, is considered as an ultimate goal that can lead to a near perfect Li metal anode, which has been pursued for long time. However, the currently prevailing strategies have not been achieved. Therefore, achieving the aforementioned ideal SEI film still remains a grand challenge. Anyway, strategies to build better SEI film have been exploring. What researchers can do is to approach these standards as soon as possible and create a balance between inorganic species and organic matrix.

Several inorganic compounds have been frequently reported as the effective components in the SEI film, including LiF, Li3N, Li2O, LiOH, and Li2CO3, whose diffusivity has been investigated through theory calculations [128–130]. Although bulk inorganic species show an extremely low ionic conductivity and cannot accommodate the volume change owing to the lack of the ability to flexibility, they play important roles in the electrochemical performance. Especially, LiF has become a star material in the field of rechargeable battery community. In order to better understand the microscopic structure of these inorganic compounds and transport mechanism of Li+, Ramasubramanian et al. [106,107] presented a clear picture with atomic resolution through theoretical calculations based on density functional theory (DFT), which have been recruited to predict the order of decomposition. Although theorical simulations can provide researchers with much atomic understanding on the SEI film, it is mostly based on the ideal condition, where exists a lot of assumptions. Therefore, there is a big gap between actual state and theoretical simulations.

Based on the above discussion, inorganic nanoparticles and organic matrix are frequently mentioned. In this section, we will select some representative reports to analysis their own shortcomings and strengths as follows.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Inorganic-rich components in the inner SEI layer
ce:section.ce:para: Inorganic compounds used for SEI film is common. In 2017, Zhang and colleagues [131] firstly reported that FEC can be used as an electrolyte additive and formed LiF-rich SEI film for protecting Li metal from being corroded. RLMBs using the electrolyte containing FEC additive exhibits excellent electrochemical performance (Fig. 12 a). After that, FEC has attracted growing appreciation and become a star material in battery community. Very recently, in order to better understand the FEC-induced interphase from the atomic level, Huang [132] portrayed a schematic diagram that the FEC additive is conductive to a thin and conformal F-rich SEI film to protect Li metal anodes. Such artificial SEI film can be readily destructed during Li deposition/dissolution due to the large volume variation. Although F-rich SEI film can indeed protect Li metal anodes, the fact that the fragile property of inorganic compound has to be accepted, and the schematic illustration of many cracks existing in the SEI film is a good explanation (Fig. 12b). It has been widely accepted that LiF is a key component for a stable SEI film, but how it plays a critical role in electrochemical performance due to the property of ionic insulating of the bulk LiF? Hu and colleagues [133] found that, compared with the bulk LiF, nanocrystalline LiF in the SEI film has a larger lattice parameter and a smaller grain size, which supports the transportation of Li+ in the SEI film. This can also explain why LiF has become a favored component in the SEI film in recent years.

Differently, in September 2019, Yao et al. [12] reported a compact inorganic layer formed by ex situ chemical reactions between Li metal anode and ionic liquid as an effective approach to limit the shuttle effect of Li polysulfides (Fig. 12c). Very recently, a research team led by Cui [38] reported that a Li2O suspension electrolyte with modified Li+ solvation structure can tailor an inorganic-rich stable SEI film for achieving enhanced electrochemical performance of anode-free Li metal battery. More importantly, the researchers detailly elucidated the role of Li2O in the SEI film by using theoretical calculations and empirical analyses (Fig. 12d). It is worth noting whether inorganic-rich or pure inorganic SEI film with poor flexibility is too fragile to accommodate the volume expansion, although inorganic-rich SEI film is highly desirable.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Organic-rich components in the inner SEI layer
ce:section.ce:para: In order to better adapt the volume variation and the interfacial stability of Li metal anode during the deposition/dissolution process, flexible SEI film is highly desirable. Different from inorganic-rich or pure inorganic SEI film, an organic-rich or pure organic SEI film generally exhibits excellent flexibility. Organic polymers enjoy the first choice when taking the flexibility and good interface contact with Li metal anode into account. Representatively, Li et al. [134] reported that polyacrylic acid (PAA) can be used as a pivotal component to build smart SEI film owing to its inherent adhesive property. It is worth noting that PAA can react with Li metal to form a layer of uniform Li-ion conductive coating of LiPAA gel polymer, which not only exhibits excellent strain performance, but also regulate Li deformation while suppressing the formation of Li dendrites (Fig. 13 a). Differently, Sun et al. [135] chose another organic polymer—Polyurea to construct an ultrathin artificial SEI film for stabilizing Li metal anode by means of molecular-layer deposition (MLD). Attentively, the N-containing polar groups in Polyurea can navigate the uniform deposition of Li+ flux and effectively suppress the formation of Li dendrites during cycling process (Fig. 13b). Very recently, Wu and colleagues [10] developed a robust pure organic artificial SEI film on Li metal anodes. Compared with the SEI film consisting of inorganic nanofibers, this kind of SEI film with pure organic nanofibers can effectively suppress the formation of Li dendrites, achieving an ultrahigh-rate and large-capacity RLMBs (Fig. 13c).

In short, if the formed SEI film is of rich-inorganic species, it will prevent electrolyte from being decomposed, thus reducing the growth rate of SEI film. If the formed SEI film is organic-abundant components, a faster SEI growth rate will be observed. These previously aforementioned artificial SEI films demonstrate excellent electrochemical performances and are fueling in promoting the practical application of rechargeable batteries.

Prior to the discussion of inorganic–organic hybrid SEI film, it is necessary to present a clear definition on the Li salt and solvents of reduction potential since SEI film is a product of chemical and electrochemical reactions. Moreover, inorganic and organic compounds of SEI film are strongly dependent on the solvation structure of Li+ in electrolyte environment [38]. If the inorganic anions have a higher reduction potential and the amount of them is larger than that of the solvent in the first solvation shell, an inorganic-rich SEI film will inevitably be formed. Therefore, in-situ formed SEI film is generally composed of organic and inorganic components. In general, inorganic SEI layer has a high mechanical strength, ionic conductivity, and poor interfacial contact with Li metal anode but fragile. On the contrary, organic SEI layer possesses excellent interfacial contact with Li metal anode and a high flexibility, which can well manipulate the huge volume variation.

As we all know, the electrolyte used in RLMBs generally contains organic solvents and Li salts. Owing to the high reactivity, Li metal can immediately react with almost all organic solvents to form a layer of passivating film, covering on the surface of Li metal anode. Organic-inorganic hybrid components derived from the decomposition of solvents or anions are frequently reported in recent years. The advantages of inorganic–organic hybrid SEI film as the products of chemical and electrochemical reactions is preeminent. In recent years, more and more electrolyte engineering strategies have been reported to construct stable SEI film for extending the cycle lifetime of RLMBs. These strategies can be largely divided into two categories: solvent-derived SEI film and anion-driven SEI film. It is worth noting that amorphous components are from the decomposition of solvent or anion.

Theoretically, organic solvents can be reduced to form organic and inorganic components when they are contacted with Li metal anode. More precisely, the segment containing carbon can form organic components, whereas carbon-free inorganic segment can be reduced to form inorganic ones. Typically, in 2018, writing in Advanced Materials, Zhang’s research group [136] reported a simple strategy to achieve a dual-layered interface for protecting Li metal anode by directly immersing Li metal into FEC solvent. It can be seen that the dual-layered interface is characterized by organic components on the top and abundant inorganic species in the bottom. Although this approach can achieve a dendrite-free Li metal anode, compact inorganic species in the bottom are fragile and cannot accommodate the volume expansion during the Li plating process. In 2020, Wang et al. [137] noticed the limitation of pure organic SEI film and inorganic-rich SEI film, and designed an organic/inorganic hybrid SEI film with a smooth surface (Fig. 14 a). Of note, this structure is similar to that of Zhang’s research group and cannot effectively regulate the volume expansion during operation, despite its improved electrochemical performance of battery. Differently, Kang et al. [138] reported a top-down reverse SEI film via a facile reaction between the Li surface and n-terminal alcohols (Fig. 14b). Significantly, this structure can effectively reduce the interfacial resistance of battery and the overpotential of Li deposition. Although the aforementioned two models of SEI film did improve the electrochemical performance of batteries, there is no answer to which structure is better. With this regard, inspired by the dual-protective layers of natural SEI film, Zhao et al. [139] designed a dual structure of SEI film by combining atomic layer deposition (ALD) and MLD, as shown in Fig. 14c. One is the organic alucone as the outer layer and inorganic Al2O3 as the inner layer, the other is the inorganic Al2O3 as the outer layer and organic alucone as the inner layer. The authors compared the electrochemical performance of Li-Li symmetric cells and found that the organic alucone as the outer layer and inorganic Al2O3 as the inner layer showed a better electrochemical performance. Logically, this work confirmed the structure effectiveness of SEI film on the surface of Li metal electrodes.

In recent years, the reactive polymeric composite layers are widely employed to enhance the stability of SEI film and endow long-term cycling performance of Li metal anodes. For example, Zhao et al. [115] reported a hybrid Li polysulfidophosphate/polymer cross-linking SEI film that can effectively protect Li metal anode. From the schematic diagram, it can be seen that the polymer is distributed throughout the SEI film, while inorganic species is distributed in the polymer matrix (Fig. 14d). In fact, this kind of structure of SEI film is similar to the solid electrolyte consisting of inorganic nanocrystalline dispersed in organic polymers, which can manipulate the volume expansion during Li deposition. Although they are not presented at the atomic level, these novel structures indeed help readers to better understand SEI film.
In a word, all of the inorganic, organic, and inorganic–organic components used to architect SEI film should be completely and compactly covered on the surface of Li metal anode.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Composite level properties of SEI film
ce:section.ce:para: From the properties of these inorganic materials aforementioned, it is impossible to use a single component for constructing the SEI film to meet all requirements of an ideal SEI film in the last chapter. It seems that the combination of inorganic crystals and organic polymer materials is a good choice. In recent years, many attempts have been confirmed that such a combination can effectively enhance the electrochemical performance of Li metal batteries [44]. However, effective guidelines on how to determine the composite level properties of SEI film are still lacking. As we all know, the ionic conductivity is one of the most important physicochemical properties of SEI film and has a significant impact on the electrochemical performances of LMBs. A fast Li+ transport can achieve a uniform Li+ distribution and Li deposition, thus suppressing the growth of Li dendrites.

In recent years, various strategies have been developed to design stable SEI film on the surface of Li metal electrodes, which can mainly be divided into two categories: artificial SEI film and in-situ SEI film. In the following section, we will briefly discuss.

Before discussing the strategies for artificial SEI film and in-situ SEI film, it is necessary to discuss the methods for surface pretreatment of Li metal. As we mentioned in Section 2, owing to the high reactivity of Li metal, the naturally formed SEI film on its surface is generally unstable and tend to induce nonuniform Li+ flux and nonuniform Li deposition, thus promoting the formation and growth of Li dendrites, meanwhile be punctured by Li dendrites during the subsequent cycles. A considerable amount of research has demonstrated that naturally formed SEI film is unstable [140,141]. Therefore, to design more satisfied SEI film for stabilizing Li metal and achieving excellent electrochemical performance, researchers have to adopt effective strategies to pretreat the surface of Li metal, including mechanical processing (pattern processing and physical polishing) [142–146], chemical polishing [147–149], and electrochemical polishing [150], and some typical cases are shown in Fig. 15 . Among these methods, it seems that chemical polishing is more effective for removing the surface oxide layer.

Artificial SEI film, also called as ex-situ SEI film, has been widely considered as a promising solution for stabilizing Li metal electrodes. In recent years, there are many strategies fabricating ex-situ SEI film, including chemical vapor deposition (CVD) [151–153], physical vapor deposition (PVD) (including magnetron sputtering and vacuum evaporation) [20,154,155] ALD [139,156], MLD [135,139,156–159], Molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) [160], which play an important role in fabrication of ultrathin film. In this section, we will detailly discuss this specific content by choosing some representative cases as follows.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Ultrathin film fabrication techniques for nanosized artificial SEI film
ce:section.ce:para: CVD is a high-end technique that can enable the fabrication of atomic-layer thickness thin film. In order to design a stable SEI film with superior chemical and mechanical stability, and high ion transport, a research group led by Archer [152] employed CVD technique to deposit an ultrathin conformal zwitterionic polymeric protective film on the surface of Li metal. Of note, zwitterionic moieties can regulate the solvation structure of the Li+, which can achieve excellent electrochemical performance of RLMBs.

PVD can also precisely regulate the composition and thickness of thin film. Therefore, this technique is frequently used to fabricate SEI film on the surface of Li metal electrodes. As a typical representative of PVD, magnetron sputtering (MS) can controllably deposit the thickness of ultrathin film under a vacuum condition to enable uniform protective film with a desired thickness. For instance, Cha and colleagues [11] reported a scalable sputter process to fabricate a layer of 10 nm-thickness two-dimensional (2D) MoS2 film with of on the surface of Li metal that can effectively stabilize Li metal, greatly promoting the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries. In addition to MoS2, other materials, including amorphous carbon [161], C60 [20], Si [155], Mg [20], LiF [162], MgF2 [181], ZnO [163], Sb-doping Li3PO4 [164], and Li3PO4 [165], have also been developed as stable SEI films on the surface of Li metal electrodes by MS technique.

ALD can exquisitely control the composition and thickness of thin film and has been recognized as a powerful thin film deposition technique for interface engineering in energy storage and conversion system [166], so as to it is widely used to fabricate SEI film on the surface of Li metal. More importantly, the as-obtained SEI films have been confirmed to be effective in stabilizing Li metal electrodes. Representatively, Kozen et al. [156] pioneeringly proposed that a 14-nm-thick Al2O3 film on the surface of Li metal via ALD process can effectively prevent organic electrolyte from decomposition. In fact, Al2O3 film is common in aluminum (Al) used for the current collector of cathodes in RLIBs since dense Al2O3 thin film can protect Al metal from further corrosion. Therefore, it is not surprising to utilize Al2O3 thin film as a stable film of Li metal anodes.

MLD is also considered as a kind of powerful nanoscale film fabrication technique, which can fabricate pure polymer SEI film and organic–inorganic hybrid SEI film. For instance, in 2019, for the first time, a research group led by Sun [135] designed an ultrathin organic film of “polyurea” by using MLD as SEI film of Li metal electrodes to increase the cycling stability of RLMBs. Subsequently, Sun’s group [157,159] reported an organic–inorganic hybrid SEI film as an artificial SEI film on the surface of Li metal via MLD, effectively facilitating uniform Li nucleation and deposition.

Molecular beam epitaxy (MBE), as a special vacuum coating technology, can fabricate a single crystal film with dozens of atomic layers by precisely regulating the molecular beam flux, the growth temperature and the rotation/tilting of sample stage. For instance, Chen et al. [160] fabricated a ultrathin and dense Bi film by MBE, greatly improving the electrochemical performance of batteries.

In summary, the aforementioned advanced equipment, like CVD, PVD, ALD, MLD, and MBE (Fig. 16 ), can precisely control the thickness and compositions of SEI film on the surface of Li metal electrodes at the atomic scale, but they are both expensive, which partially limits its large-scale applications.

Alternatively, the chemical reaction with a gas to form an artificial SEI film on the surface of Li metal has been considered as a promising solution for stabilizing Li metal. Considering the high reactivity, Li metal can react with gas to form a surface passivating film consisting of pure-phase component, which can suppress air/water attack and Li dendrite growth. Therefore, gas processing is a common strategy that can control the pure-phase components generated on the surface of Li metal. F2 [16], Freon [15], NF3 [13], N2 [167], S vapor [168], SeS2 [169], and I2 [170], CS2-I2 steam [171], which can react with Li metal to form LiF, LiF, LiF, Li3N, Li2S, Li2S/Li2Se, LiI, and C-Li2S/LiI, respectively, as shown in Fig. 17 (top). It needs to be pointed out that Li2S is unstable and tends to generate H2S when exposed to ambient air.

In addition to these ultrathin film fabrication techniques and gas processing, solution processing, including immersing/soaking [172,173], drop coating [140,174–179], slurry coating [19], solution coating [180,181], spin coating [138,182], spray [183], melt coating [184], etc., have also been widely used to construct stable artificial SEI film, as shown in Fig. 17 (bottom). Compared with ultrathin film fabrication techniques and gas processing, solution processing is a facile method that hold great potential for large-scale applications. However, the SEI film is generally thick, which can increase the interfacial impedance.

In general, in-situ formed SEIs have more complicated components and structures than that of artificial SEI film. In order to better identify the advantages of in-situ and artificial SEI films, we select and compare the electrochemical performance of some representative components for SEI film, as shown in Table 3 . Based on the above-mentioned publications, organic polymer matrix is encouraged to be introduced into the inorganic layer for forming stable SEI film with high flexibility for further increasing the mechanical property of the SEI. Herein, we summarize and compare the artificial SEI film and in-situ SEI film in the previously reported, as shown in Table 4 . In order to better understand the specific advantages and disadvantages of various artificial SEI film, five key parameters are sketched in Fig. 18 . It is found that the thickness of artificial SEI film is generally larger than that of in-situ, and its fabrication cost obviously higher than that of in-situ SEI film. A stable artificial or in-situ SEI film both can effectively protect Li metal from corrosion. All these strategies have their own advantages and effectiveness in preparing a stable SEI film toward stabilizing Li metal anode. From the perspective of the practical applications, the “gas reaction” and “electrolyte” score well in all the five parameters, while the “vapor deposition” has only one comparative advantage in fabricating artificial SEI film, that is, thickness [73].

Remarkable achievements have been made to design stable SEI film on the surface of Li metal anode, but many issues still need to be addressed. Firstly, some artificial SEI films created by pretreatment process are still far away from satisfactory. When the methods used for coin cells showing excellent electrochemical performance is transferred to pouch cells, the performances are unsatisfactory. Therefore, a transition from coin cell to pouch cell is necessary when evaluating practicality of the method. Secondly, the relation between the structure of the SEI film and electrochemical performance of battery remains to be elucidated. Thirdly, more index to evaluate the usefulness of SEI film under extreme condition should be considered.

SEI film are highly related to electrolytes and has been considered as the critical components to support rechargeable battery chemistry. Electrolyte, as an indispensable component in RLMBs, is generally composed of Li salts, solvents, and additives, which must demand to form a robust SEI film to enable the cycling stability of RLMBs. Therefore, optimizing electrolyte is regarded as a promising strategy to in-situ construct SEI film on the surface of Li metal. Currently, the prevailing strategies can mainly divide into two categories: electrolyte additive and functional electrolyte, and some representative cases are summarized in Fig. 19 . In this section, we will detailly discuss this specific content as follows.

Additives play a crucial role in the formation and stability of the SEI film on Li metal anode and have been intensively investigated in RLMBs. In recent years, various additives have been developed to incorporate LiF into the SEI film, including fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) [185,186], vinylene carbonate (VC) [187,188], and LiF nanoparticles [189]. In addition, boron (B)-based additives have been widely used in RLMBs and recently was summarized by our group [190], and the readers can consult it for more information.

Solvent-derived SEI film, especially solvent additive-derived SEI film, is frequently reported in recent years. Typically, FEC and VC have been acknowledged as star additives in the field of rechargeable batteries. It is worth noting that Xu et al. [188] have revealed the atomic to nanoscale origin of the VC additive using cryo-EM. Very recently, Xin and colleagues [191] reported a novel solid polymer electrolyte by using FEC additive to control the formation of SEI film, achieving a ultralong cycle lifetime and excellent electrochemical performance.

In addition to solvents as additives, some Li salts are also used additives. LiPF6 is the typical additive to generate LiF-rich SEI film [30]. In addition, LiNO3 has been considered as a star additive in the field of Li-S battery [192,193] since it can readily form a layer of passivating surface film, which can effectively inhibit the shuttle phenomenon of soluble LiPSs between cathode and anode. Very recently, Xin and colleagues [191] reported a novel solid polymer electrolyte by using FEC additive to control the formation of SEI film, achieving a ultralong cycle lifetime and excellent electrochemical performance. A research team led by Zhang frequently reported anion-derived SEI film [194–196]. Anion-derived SEI film is common and can be divided into two categories: additives and high-concentration electrolytes (HCEs). LiPF6 is the typical additive to generate LiF-rich SEI film [30]. In addition, LiNO3 has been considered as a star additive in the field of Li-S battery [192,193]. This is because it can readily form a layer of passivating surface film, which can effectively inhibit the shuttle phenomenon of soluble LiPSs between cathode and anode.

Although these additives have been used to improve the electrochemical performance of RLMBs, an essential understanding on how do these additives work is still lacking, which is worthy of further investigation in future research. On the other hand, HCEs have also attracted extensive attention in recent years [33–37]. Different from additives, in HCEs system, most solvent molecules can be excluded from the solvation shell Li+. Park et al. [197] screened various Li salts (including LiTFSI, LiFSI, LiPF6, and LiFSA) with different dissociation capabilities and detailly analyzed the distinct occupation of the solvation environment by FEC. Interestingly, the researchers found that LiTFSI is the most suitable one for inducing the FEC-derived interface, and batteries using unique electrolyte exhibit excellent cycling performance since it possesses superior dissociation as a Li salt and high lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) energy level. Moreover, the formation of free FEC molecules can be promoted when DME solvent with high solvation energy was introduced into the electrolyte system. Whether solvent-derived or anion-derived SEI film, there is no identical SEI film in two different environments since the components of SEI film formed on the surface of Li metal is strongly dependent on the Li salts, solvents, and working condition of batteries.

Although these mentioned strategies have been reported to be effective in controlling the formation of SEI film, they are poorly understood at the atomic level. Very recently, Park et al. [197] screened various Li salts (including LiTFSI, LiFSI, LiPF6, and LiFSA) with different dissociation capabilities and detailly analyzed the distinct occupation of the solvation environment by FEC. Interestingly, the researchers found that LiTFSI is the most suitable one for inducing the FEC-derived interface, and batteries using unique electrolyte exhibit excellent cycling performance since it possesses superior dissociation as a Li salt and LUMO energy level. Moreover, the formation of free FEC molecules can be promoted when DME solvent with high solvation energy was introduced into the electrolyte system.

In short, additives have been used to improve the electrochemical performance of RLMBs, while an essential understanding on how do these additives function is still lacking, which is worthy of further investigation in future research.

In recent years, fluorinated electrolytes have been intensively developed and confirmed to be able to promote the formation of a LiF-rich SEI film on deposited Li metal and achieve excellent electrochemical performance [29,66,198–208]. How to design inorganic/organic SEI film with dynamic stability is still a painful problem in the current research of RLMBs. Fortunately, some excellent reports have provided the readers with some ideas that tailoring rational electrolytes from the molecular level could be a plausible direction to create a stable SEI film for building better RLMBs (Fig. 19) [26,29,35,198,206,209–213]. In particular, Bao, Cui and colleagues [26,29,211,212,214] have elaborately synthesized a series of fluorinated-1,2-diethoxyethane (DEE) solvents by iteratively changing the position and number of fluorinated functional groups from -CF3 groups to -CHF2, to obtain stable solvents for RLMBs and achieve superior electrochemical performances. These excellent research works can provide more creative ideas for building better RLMBs. Although fluorinated electrolytes have attracted worldwide research enthusiasm, highly fluorinated or perfluorinated solvents are not necessarily desirable. A recent publication highlighted by Yu et al. [214] that the degree of fluoridation of the electrolyte also needs to be fine-tuned, and the authors clearly pointed out that only partially fluorinated electrolyte can achieve a better electrochemical performance for LMBs. It needs to be pointed out that the formation of a stable SEI film highly depends on the selected electrolyte [215]. Furthermore, poor solvation (the stability of Li metal anode) and good solvation (fast Li+ ions transportation) needs an optimal balance by finely tuning the solvation environment of the solvent [29].

Recent studies state that fluorinated electrolytes can promote the formation of LiF-rich and fluorinated organic species SEI film, which are conductive to the electrochemical performance of RLMBs [26,29,66,198,205,211,215]. However, it can be seen that the LiF species is locally distributed, accompanied by many Li2O nanocrystals embedded in a thin but robust amorphous polymer in the SEI film [96]. As Li et al. [77] mentioned, the nanostructure of SEI film is the crucial factor to the electrochemical performance of RLMBs. Therefore, finding a balance distribution between inorganic components and organic ones in the SEI film from the atomic perspective is of imperative significance.

Overall, tailoring electrolyte recipes can be deemed to change the solvation structure of Li+ in the electrolyte, further regulating the formation of SEI film. Whether electrolyte additives and functional electrolytes, LiF is always frequently mentioned in the literature.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Construction of three-dimensional (3D)-structured Li metal electrodes
ce:section.ce:para: Li metal electrodes can undergo significant volume changes during repetitive cycling process. In recent years, various 3D host materials have been developed to alleviate the huge volume expansion, including Ni foam [216,217], Cu foam [218], 3D Cu foil [219–222], 3D Cu nanowire network [223], carbon foam [224], carbon cloth [225], carbon nanofiber [52], graphene oxide [226], g-C3N4 [227], polymeric matrix [228,229], and so on. Very recently, our group detailly summarized the recent progress on enhancing the lithiophilicity of hosts for 3D-structured Li metal electrodes [230], and the readers can consult it for more detailed information.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Evaluation methods for the stability of SEI structure
ce:section.ce:para: As we mentioned above, a series of strategies, including artificial and in-situ approaches, have been adopted to construct so called “stable” SEI film, but it is hard to determine which strategy is the best one by comparing cycling lifetime of Li-Li symmetric cells under different current densities and area capacities owing to the lack of unified standards. To the best of our knowledge, so far, there has no publication specifically proposing general standards to evaluate the stability of SEI film. We have an attempt to fulfil this blank. To this end, some representative cases are listed to detailly elucidate these evaluation methods, including stability test in ambient air, the cycling lifetime of Li-Li symmetric cells and full batteries, the CE of Li-Cu half cells and the full-batteries cycling performance, cryo-EM, atomic force microscopy (AFM), electrochemical quartz crystal microbalance (EQCM), XTM, and theoretical calculations (Fig. 20 ).

Based on such a conventional recognition, a stable SEI film is an ionic conductor but electronic insulator, which means that it cannot accept electrons and occur chemical reaction. In other words, Li metal can be stably stored in ambient air if a layer of robust and dense SEI film is formed on its surface. Fig. 21 shows the digital photos of Li metal electrodes formed a stable SEI film [17,19,231]. It can be seen that the stability is different under different humidity for bare Li metal, while some specific Li metals protected by artificial SEI film can store for a longer time in ambient air. Therefore, researchers are encouraged to test the storage time of Li metal electrodes in ambient conditions for judging the stability of SEI film.

In recent years, several research teams have developed air-stable Li metal electrodes and achieved some encouraging achievements [17,19–21,231–233]. For instance, Shen et al. [19] reported an inorganic-rich LiF SEI film on the surface of Li metal anode by incorporating graphite fluoride (GF) in molten Li at 250 °C. Of particular note, the Li bonds strongly with the GF to form a LiF protective layer, and the as-obtained GF-LiF-Li composite can effectively remain its original structure even in a humid air with a relative humidity of 20 to 35% for over 24 h (Fig. 22 a). In addition, designing organic–inorganic hybrid SEI film can simultaneously inherit the merits of flexibility of organic SEI film and mechanical stability of inorganic SEI film. Representatively, Liu et al. [21] reported a novel dual-layered artificial SEI film featured with organics (-COPO3-, -(CO)2PO2-, and -(CO)3PO) on the top and inorganic (Li3PO4) at the bottom (Fig. 22b). Synergistically, this kind of artificial SEI film can facilitate the uniform deposition of Li+, enabling dendrite-free Li metal batteries. It is worth noting that Li metal anodes with a protective film is stable in a humid air with a relative humidity of 25%.

In order to develop safer Li metal batteries, researchers always expect that SEI film on the surface of Li metal can prevent Li metal anode from corrosion even in water. To this end, a research group led by Yang [184] reported an air-stable and waterproof SEI film consisting of a wax-poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO) hybrid material on the surface of Li metal electrode by a simple dip coating process (Fig. 22c). Interestingly, the as-obtained Li metal electrodes can remain stable for 24 h in ambient air even with the relative humidity of 70% while retaining about 85% capacity. In addition, inspired by the umbrella consisting of flexible and hydrophobic cloth, Liu et al. [233] designed a hydrophobic composite polymer electrolyte and covered it on the surface of Li metal electrode and designed a kind of safe Li-O2 battery with excellent flexibility in ambient air (Fig. 22d). It needs to be pointed out that bare Li metal is stable in a dry room, which endows the possibility of large-scale production of Li metal batteries. A recent study by Li et al. [234] revealed the reason why metals can be stored stably in dry air by using in-situ environmental transmission electron microscopy, and the authors concluded that the stability of Li metal in dry air highly depends on the formation of dense Li2O layer on the surface of Li metal (Fig. 22e). There are two excellent reviews summarizing the research progress [235,236], and the readers can consult them for more information.

In short, air-stable Li metal anode means that the fabrication cost can be greatly decreased. From a perspective of economy and operationality, artificial SEI film obtained by solution pretreatment has been considered as a promising strategy for large-scale manufacturing.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Long cycle lifetime of Li-Li symmetric cells
ce:section.ce:para: The cycling lifetime of Li-Li symmetric cells can be used as a descriptor of stability of SEI film, which is closely associated with the CE of Li deposition and dissolution. In theory, the longer the cycle life is, the more stable the SEI film is. Before discussing the cycling lifetime of Li-Li symmetric cells, herein, it is necessary to introduce two common failure phenomena. One is the low polarization caused by the short-circuiting of batteries, the other is high polarization after long cycling. In general, whether low polarization or high polarization for Li-Li symmetric cells plating/stripping can both result in battery failure, which should be ascribed to the unstable SEI film formed on the surface of Li metal electrodes. Currently, most reports are based on a sudden voltage change to judge battery short circuit, meaning that both SEI film and separator are punctured by Li dendrites. To date, ultralong lifetime for Li-Li symmetric cells have been widely reported in the literature (Fig. 23 a) [237,238]. However, it should be noted that soft short circuit phenomenon is common in symmetric cells and generally exhibit a relatively low polarization voltage [239], creating an ultra-stable illusion, thus leading to a misleading that the SEI film formed on the surface of the Li metal electrode is stable. Therefore, it is urgently needed to propose some pertinent test protocols and quantificational standards for judging the stability of SEI film in future research.
In short, stable cycling performance of Li-Li symmetric cells is highly dependent on the stability of SEI film.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Interfacial impedance of Li-Li symmetric cell
ce:section.ce:para: Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) a simple, practical and non-destructive technique widely used in battery analysis [240]. Interfacial impedance can be used as another important index to evaluate the stability of SEI film. In theory, if a stable SEI film forms on the surface of Li metal, the interfacial impedance will keep a fixed value. Fig. 23b depicts the EIS evolution of a Li anode formed an artificial SEI film for different rest times at open circuit condition [241]. From the Nyquist plots of the Li-Li symmetric cells, there is no significant change in interface impedance, meaning that the as-prepared artificial SEI film is stable.

ce:section.ce:section-title: High CE of Li-Cu half cells
ce:section.ce:para: High CE can be used as another important index to evaluate the stability of SEI film formed on the surface of Li metal anode. High CE can be ascribed to the reversible electrochemical reactions, which means a stable SEI film. Understandably, high CE means that there is little Li lose. In other words, formed SEI film on the surface of Li metal electrode is stable. Correspondingly, battery with a relatively high CE can cycle for a longer time than that of with a relatively low CE (Fig. 23c) [242]. Theoretically, if the SEI film formed on the surface of Li metal electrode is stable enough, CE will reach 100%.
