However, in practical condition, the CE cannot reach 100% owing to the parasitic reaction during cycling process.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Long-terms cycling stability and CE of full-batteries
ce:section.ce:para: Although the cycling lifetime of Li-Li symmetric cells and CE of Li-Cu half cells are significant, they cannot fully reflect the actual condition of the full batteries. Representatively, Xiao et al. [243] deeply discuss the fundamental understanding of CE and uncover its true meaning in rechargeable batteries. Therefore, the remain retention capacity of a battery after certain cycling can be calculated by the equation: capacity retention = (CE)n, where n represents the cycle number. If a full battery cycles 1000 times with more than 90% capacity retention, the CE would be >99.99% (Fig. 23d). In this condition, it can be considered that the formed SEI film on Li metal surface is stable.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Solubility of the SEI film into electrolyte solution
ce:section.ce:para: It has been reported that once solvent-derived organic components form in the SEI film, they can undergo obvious dissolution [244–246], which can accelerate the deterioration of battery performance, reduce the solvation ability of SEI components and promote the formation of insoluble SEI components, which can minimize SEI dissolution. Recently, Stetson et al. [244] confirmed that temperature has an important impact on the stability of SEI film. Moreover, SEI film dissolution occurs at significantly faster rates at higher temperature conditions (Fig. 24 a). Very recently, we notice that Cui and colleagues [246] systematically quantified the solubility of SEI film by using operando EQCM and established a correlation between SEI dissolution and cycling performance of LMBs (Fig. 24b and c). The authors pointed out that SEI film mass loss due to dissolution during resting at open circuit, which is considered as a major contributor to toward capacity loss among battery electrolytes.

In short, the stability of SEI film highly depends on the solubility of organic components in the SEI film formed in each electrolyte system. Therefore, a rational designing of electrolyte is the key to suppress the dissolution of SEI film and improve battery performances.

In addition to electrochemical methods, a various array of characterization techniques ranging from microscopy to spectroscopy have been recruited to scrutinize the stability of SEI film, including atomic force microscopic (AFM) [134,247–249], secondary ion mass spectroscopy (SIMS) [91], and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) [46,250,251], EQCM [247], Raman spectroscopy [252], nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) [253], and reflection interference microscopy [254], which, to some extent, aid researcher to understand SEI film. In order to better understand the SEI film, some traditional electrochemical analysis, like electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) [240,255,256] and titration gas chromatography (TGC) [257,258], have also been applied in recent years. Of note, EIS, is a common and nondestructive technique for the internal condition, whose testing results can contain almost all the internal information of the electrochemical system. There are several outstanding reviews summarizing the characterization techniques of SEI film [60,259,260]. The readers are suggested to further learn more details and other characterization techniques.

When justifying the effectiveness of a specific characterization technique, it is important to consider its advantages and limitations compared to other characterization tools. For instance, AFM is a powerful characterization one for analyzing the surface morphology and topography of materials and can provide high-resolution images of the SEI film. When it comes to nanoscale, cryo-EM is an emerging technique that is commonly used for analyzing the structure of biological molecules, like proteins and viruses. In recent years, it has been widely acknowledged to characterize the SEI film and provide high-resolution images. In order to identify the stability of SEI film, in this section, we will mainly discuss the three characterization techniques: cryo-EM, AFM, and EQCM as follows.

Cryo-EM has been regarded as a powerful tool for the study of battery materials and interfaces [75,93,261,262], so as to it enjoys a paramount priority when researchers intend to observe the atomic structure. It is in 2017 that its emergence and practical value for the high-resolution capability of biomolecules was awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry. Attentively, it is exactly in the same year that cryo-EM characterization technique was recruited by Cui and colleagues to characterize SEI film, for the first time. After that, cryo-EM characterization technique has received increasing appreciation, and achieved a series of exciting discoveries in the field of battery [75,77,96,188,191,250,263–265]. There are several perspectives and reviews summarizing the major breakthroughs by cryo-EM [259,261,266,267].

Given the highly sensitivity to air or moisture of SEI film, the cryo-transfer process can retain the initial state and fresh structure of SEI film, gaining a convincing result. Therefore, the preparation process of sample is of great importance. There are three recommended methods to prepare the samples. The first one is by using cryogenically focused ion beam (cryo-FIB) scanning electronic microscopic (SEM) to mount the sample on a copper (Cu) grid, which is subsequently loaded onto a cryo-holder in liquid nitrogen and transferring the assembly to the TEM chamber after closing the shutter. The second one is to directly deposit the sample on a Cu grid, and subsequently transfer into the EM chamber under argon (Ar) protection after placing it to a cooling holder in the Ar-filled glove box [266]. The third is to disperse the cycled electrodes into an electrolyte solvent, and subsequently drop the dispersed solution onto a Cu grid before freezing and transferring into the EM chamber [75]. Through storing the samples under a liquid nitrogen environment before transferring to the EM chamber, it is possible to detect the atomic structure of the SEI film.

In recent years, researchers have acquired different types of microscopic images of SEI film by recruiting cryo-EM (Fig. 25 a) [9,29,75,77,90,268]. It can be seen that these microscopic images can be classified into three categories, including mosaic model, multilayer model and amorphous model. In terms of mosaic model, inorganic crystallites unevenly dispersed in the organic matrix, and Li+ tend to be localized plating and stripping, giving rise to the formation of inactive or dead Li on the surface of Li metal anode. For the multilayer model, in the outer region of the organic matrix, there is a well-crystallized inorganic species. The third is the amorphous model, which consists of inorganic amorphous matrix, as opposed to the mosaic model (Fig. 25b). Obviously, three models are different in crystallographic form and morphological distribution of inorganics in the organic matrix.

As we mentioned before, a stable SEI film should be featured by flexibility to alleviate the volume expansion during cycling process. Based on the microscopic images recorded by cryo-EM, organic and inorganic components both exist in the SEI film. AFM, as a force-based characterization technique, provide a platform for the detection of elastic region (organic oligomer) and plastic region (inorganic species) of SEI film [21]. Moreover, it can afford a 3D surface profile for the samples [134,269]. It is worth noting that AFM can work well in ambient air or a liquid environment, and the samples examined can be an insulator. Therefore, it can be considered as an effective measurement to characterize the SEI film.

In general, AFM has two operation modes: contact mode and tapping mode. When a small force is applied, elastic region of SEI film can be deformed. When a large force is applied, plastic region can be detected (Fig. 26 a) [270]. In order to rapidly evaluate the effectiveness of SEI film formed on the surface of Li metal anodes, Wang et al. [249] purposely constructed single-layer and multilayer SEI films containing LiF and organic species to establish the standards from AFM nanoindentation features. The authors found that different SEI films show different indentation feature, including sawtooth, ramping-slope, basin-like, plateau, and plateau-sawtooth features for inorganic-rich SEI film, inorganic–organic hybrid SEI film, organic-rich SEI film, inner layer ROLi and outer layer LiF, inner layer LiF, middle layer ROLi and outer layer LiF (donated as I-O-I), respectively. The corresponding force–displacement of the single-layer and multilayer SEI films upon tip pressing are depicted in (Fig. 26 and c). These nanoindentation features can be used as additional standard to evaluate SEI film. Interestingly, among these Li metal electrodes pretreated by SEI films, Li-Li symmetric cell with multi-layered I-O-I SEI film exhibit the best cycling stability.

In addition to these features, the mechanical stability of SEI film has an important impact on the cycling performance of LMBs. As a representative example, very recently, Huang and colleagues [44] reported an in-situ bilayer structural SEI film enabled by using trioxane-modulated electrolytes. In order to probe the mechanical stability of SEI film on the surface of Li metal anode, the authors specially designed a in situ electrochemical cell through in situ AFM characterization technique. As a result, the force curves demonstrate that a force of 439 nN applied by the AFM probe could pierce the bilayer structural SEI film, while a smaller force of 211 nN is required to pierce the single layer LiF-rich SEI film with. Obviously, the bilayer structural SEI film consisting of a LiF-rich inner layer and a polymer outer layer indicates a better mechanical stability that that of the single layer structural LiF-rich SEI film. Moreover, the cycling lifetime of the cell with bilayer structural SEI film is much longer than that of single layer SEI film.

In order to gain more reliable information, in situ AFM is commonly used to provide the vivid morphological changes of the SEI film. In recent years, scientific researchers have gained different microscopic images of SEI film by means of in situ AFM [134,248]. From these microscopic images recorded by in situ AFM, it can be found that SEI film is of dynamic evolution during cycling process (Fig. 26d). Theoretically, Li dendrites generate during plating process. However, interestingly, the researchers confirmed that Li dendrites can also be generated during stripping process owing to the uneven stripping of Li [134].

EQCM, as an extremely cheap and non-destructive characterization technique, has been considered to aid to reveal the underlying mechanisms from the bulk to interface [271]. Of particular note, QCM is an ultra-sensitive weight detector, which can provide researchers with in-situ information about the mass change on the surface of electrodes. More precisely, EQCM can record the mass change (Δm) vs. charge change (dq) in the electrode attached to the quartz surface with a relatively high accuracy. Logically, EQCM is a powerful tool that can help to understand the stability of SEI film. Representatively, Liu et al. [247] recruited in-situ EQCM for real-time detecting the formation of SEI film on the anode by cyclic voltammetry (CV) cathodic scan (Fig. 27 a). Although the formation process of SEI film on graphite is different from that of Li metal anode, this work provides a valuable reference for researchers to effectively evaluate the stability of SEI film. Very recently, Sayavong and co-authors [246] systematically quantified and compared the solubility of SEI film on the surface Li metal anode under ether-based electrolytes by using in-operando EQCM. Interestingly, the authors found that SEI film can be dissolved to as a major factor to the differences in electrolytes passivity and electrochemical performance of battery. If there is a stable SEI film on the surface of Li metal electrode, the mass of SEI film will not change.

XTM is a powerful characterization tool that can detect the local morphology and composition of material via non-destructive 3D imaging with spatial resolution. Considering the huge volume fluctuation during plating/stripping process, it is necessary to discuss the structure evolution of Li metal electrodes. General speaking, when they start with a flat surface (or 3D electrode), over time, the Li metal electrodes tends to become mossy or highly porous with a considerable increase in thickness, and further forming Li dendrites, accompanied by huge volume expansion, which can lead to the continuous rupture/reorganization of the SEI film, finally deteriorating the electrochemical performance of battery. Very recently, Matic, Xiong and colleagues [123] systematically studied the microstructure evolution of Li metal during plating and stripping by using operando XTM measurements, and the readers can consult it for more detailed information.

Although cryo-EM, AFM and XTM have been widely recruited in the characterization of SEI, they can only provide a local environment, which cannot represent the whole information of the SEI film. Moreover, there are still certain difficulties providing experimental evidence of the atomic details owing to the complexity of samples preparation and the difficulty of instrument actual operation, theoretical calculations based on molecular dynamics (MD) provide a possible solution from the atomic level [272,273]. However, unfortunately, its implementation is restricted by its high computational costs and limited space (usually 2–3 nm). As we mentioned before, the thickness of the SEI film is usually ∼ 20 nm. In order to track the reaction process between Li metal and electrolyte from the actual distance, recently, Yang and co-authors [274] applied the reactive force field to simulate the formation process of SEI film on the surface of Li metal at scales of 10–100 nm under [TFSI][BMIM] ionic liquid (IL), providing the atomistic details of the SEI film. Moreover, the calculation results show that, at room temperature, the thickness of the formed SEI film is ∼ 10 nm consisting of two layers: one layer is a thickness of 2.5 nm ordered inorganic layer close to the side of Li metal; the other layer is a thickness of 7.5 nm porous organic layer approaching to the side of IL electrolyte (Fig. 27b).

In brief, these approaches aforementioned both can provide the researchers with a powerful function for the atomic structure of SEI film, but they have their own merits and demerits. It seems that single characterization techniques or theoretical calculations are not sufficient to fully reveal the veil of SEI film. Therefore, further research on the fined structure of SEI film by means of integrating advanced in situ and operando characterization techniques with more high-end theoretical calculations is highly desirable in the future [254].

After more than 40 years exploration, tremendous achievements have been made on SEI film. Up to now, sporadic research on the SEI film has been ongoing, while the understanding on it continues to deepen. In this review, we extract the major breakthroughs on the SEI film, cover some representative inorganic species, organic components, and inorganic–organic hybrid components used for SEI film, and discuss the transportation mechanism of Li+ in the SEI film, summarize chemical/electrochemical methods, characterization techniques, and theoretical simulations used for evaluating the stability of SEI film, and present the designing strategies of a stable SEI film.

We make no attempt to cover all cases related to SEI film, instead select some representative examples to elucidate the microscopic structure of SEI film, providing the readers with critical insights into SEI film and find some possible opportunities in creating a uniform ordered distribution in future research. Although SEI film has been widely studied, the nucleation and growth mode of SEI film is still the missing piece, especially for the fined structure at the atomic level, which is worthy of further investigation in future research. In addition, these materials used to construct so-called stable SEI films should be reexamined. As we all know, SEI film is an ionic conductor but electronic insulator. Many conductive materials, such as amorphous carbon, C60, Mg, Bi, have been developed to construct an artificial SEI film on the surface of Li metal anodes and achieved excellent electrochemical performances. As a matter of fact, these materials do not simultaneously meet the requirements of SEI.

Recent years have seen continuous breakthroughs on energy density and cycle lifetime via elaborate strategies (Fig. 28 ) [6,44,83,92,275–280]. To be specific, the energy density of pouch cells has progressed continuously from 350 to 758 Wh kg−1 (this data is from the 7th National Li-S Batteries Symposium in 2023), but the cycling lifespan only culminate 600 cycles [92]. It seems that the tailorable energy density [5] and cycle lifetime of RLMBs cannot be compatible. Even so, more and more feasible approaches are attempting to simultaneously achieve high energy density and long cycling lifetime, which has been considered as the future goal in the field of LMBs.
Although impressive advances have been made, some challenging but promising directions remain and should be further carefully considered in future research (Fig. 29 ).

(1) Designing high-crystal-quality SEI film. Most research works appreciate the composition rather than distribution of inorganic crystal grains in the SEI film. As a matter of fact, according to the transportation mechanism of Li+ in the SEI film, crystal quality is more important than composition in the SEI film. Researchers always hope that stable SEI film can be tailored by a feasible strategy for upgrading the electrochemical performance of RLMBs. If the inner SEI film is composed of single inorganic component, including Li2O, Li2S, Li2Se, Li3N, LiF, LiCl, LiI, LiOH, Li2CO3, and so on, unavoidably, it would rupture during charge/discharge process owing to the volume change during plating process. Considering these factors, such as band gap (electronic insulating), diffusion barrier (ion conductive), mechanical strength, thermodynamic stability, and surface energy, LiF seems to be one of the most powerful inorganic components in the SEI film that prevent Li metal from dendrite growth. If LiF can be combined with flexible organic/polymer components, the resulting SEI film is capable of regulating volume changes. The thematic issues of Advanced Energy Materials published in 2021 comprehensively covered the research progress of LiF [62], and the readers can refer to get more information. In recent 3 years, most of the researches are concerned about the content of LiF and the transport mechanism of Li+ in the SEI film. If the transport mechanism of Li+ in each inorganic SEI component can be vigorously studied, a rational design of stable SEI film will be highly desirable.

(2) Constructing “single-crystal-like” SEI film. A considerable amount of research has focused on the study of composition rather than crystal quality. As a matter of fact, it is crystal quality that matters Li+ transformation. Therefore, improving the crystal quality towards a ‘single-crystal-like’ SEI film should represent a step towards enhancing the long-enduring stability of RLMBs. In addition, considering Li2O also can be used as the main component of SEI film, researchers are strongly suggested to design stable Li metal electrodes covered by pure Li2O by regulating the storage time in high-pure O2 atmosphere.

(3) Developing single crystal Li metal. In theory, it is the microstructure of Li metal that determines the structure of SEI film and electrochemical performance of RLMBs. It is widely accepted that commercial Li metal products is a kind of polycrystal material. As we all know, polycrystal Li metal are prone to side reactions, which greatly affect the electrochemical performance of RLMBs, while single materials have been long pursued in in manufacturing aircraft gas turbines blades [281] and physics research [282,283]. If single Li metal electrodes are used as the anodes of RLMBs, the electrochemical performance will be greatly improved. Therefore, single Li metal deserves to be carefully considered and deeply researched in the future.

(4) Applying surface modification technology. In order to design a high-quality nanoscale single-crystal-like SEI film, such strategic approaches, including ALD and MLD, are recommended to create a conformal thin electronic insulating but ion conductive coating of uniform distribution and controllable thickness on the surface of metal electrodes, not limited to Li metal. If engineering artificial SEI film is not considered, it will be impossible to gain a SEI film with completely uniform component under organic solvent environment. Noticeably, organic and inorganic components existing in the SEI film generally present a random distribution. Organic component can provide elasticity and solvent compatibility, while the inorganic portion is mainly responsible for the ionic conductivity. Therefore, the distribution of inorganic/organic composition existing in the SEI film must remain uniform.

(5) Developing advanced characterization techniques. Experimental evidence of the formation mechanism of SEI film and transportation of Li+ in the SEI film is still deficient. Owing to the limited development of in situ/operando characterization techniques, real-time tracking of Li+ in the SEI film cannot be conducted under battery operation. Fortunately, MD simulations are considered as a powerful approach to aid the understanding of such a process. As the combination of various cutting-edge characterization techniques that are available to researchers continues to deeply explore, we strongly believe that many new results will continue to surprise the researchers in the field of RLMBs in future research. With recent dramatic progress in various advanced characterization techniques used to study the SEI film structure, we are very curious about on these issues: what is the next exciting breakthrough for this field? How will these cutting-edge techniques update our understanding on SEI film? Since the atomic resolution of SEI film are currently only distinguishable by means of cryo-EM, we envision that this characterization technique will continue to play a key role in updating our understanding on SEI film in future research. If possible, we expect that the stable SEI film could be tailored to cater for Li metal anode through machine learning (ML) in the foreseeable future. By combining the results of cryo-EM, the other characterization techniques and ML, we will gain deeper mechanistic insight into how the SEI film affect the electrochemical performance of RLMBs. Looking into the future, we envision that further breakthroughs can be made by more advanced characterization techniques, which needs to devote redoubled efforts for achieving practical applications of RLMBs by combining research institutions, universities and enterprises.

(6) Learning from LIBs. From the fundamental research to commercial applications, RLIBs integrates many innovations and breakthroughs with one system, which contains the discoveries of intercalation compounds (graphite and transition metal oxides) and electrolyte formulation (EC-based electrolyte). Surprisingly, just a single methyl difference between EC and PC could essentially upgrade the cycling stability of RLIBs, whose mechanism could only be explained by the atomic structure. Therefore, the rich knowledge gained from the field of RLIBs can potentially be applied for the future development of RLMBs. Therefore, we strongly suggest that subsequent researchers can also continue this research thought to propel the practical applications of RLMBs. Recent years have witnessed remarkable progress in the design of electrode materials and electrolytes, and the requirements for better electrode materials (cathodes and Li metal anodes) and good electrolytes have continued. However, integrating best electrode materials, separators, and electrolytes into on system cannot achieve the best performance. There is an aphorism well-circulated in the battery community: “Given the best anode, cathode, separator and electrolyte, one could produce the worst battery by simply putting them together” [284]. Obviously, future innovations and breakthroughs depend on the further optimized combination of these components in RLMBs.

Constructing stable SEI film on the surface of Li metal anode can be considered as the final piece of the puzzle to achieve large-scale deployment of RLMBs. We believe that the comprehensive understanding of SEI film in this manuscript can be treated as a good start to inspire more rational and reliable efforts toward the SEI film research. We hope that this timely review is both helpful to newcomers or researchers who already have certain understanding on the SEI film, motivating deeper research on SEI film for building better RLMBs to meet the requirements of practical applications. We strongly believed that stable and reliable SEI film will be the last piece of the puzzle for the practical applications of RLMBs. Although the roadmap towards practical applications for RLMBs is fraught with hurdles, the future is prospective. We envision that RLMBs can hatch a brand-new era to change the course of human in the foreseeable future.
